data.name: wpSaveReinventoryInSameDatabase
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par Indicate whether or not you would like to save your new project data in the same database as the one where the original project is saved by selecting "Yes" or "No".\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 Now that you have selected the database and project information to identify the data that you are remeasuring, you must decide where to save your new project data. i-Tree Eco allows you to save your remeasurement data in the same database as the existing data.\par If you would like to save your new project data in a new database, be sure to select "No." \par \f1\fs22\par } �

data.name: wpSpecifyExistingDatabase
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\par \b0 Choose the existing database that you would like to save your new project in by browsing to the folder where it is saved and selecting it. After selected, the existing database name will appear in the box.\b\par Why It's Important:\par \b0 You have decided to save your new project data in an existing database. The input that you provide here will inform i-Tree Eco that you would like all of your new project data to be saved in the selected database.\par } �

data.name: wpProjectName
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\par \b0 Enter a name for your project in the box provided.\b\par Why It's Important:\par \b0 The project name is an important setting in i-Tree Eco because it gives your project a unique identity. This is also the name that will be used in your results. \par For example, the project name will appear in the title of the tables and graphs produced by i-Tree Eco, as well as when referring to your study area in the written report.\par } �

data.name: wpSetFullInventory
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par Indicate whether or not you will be collecting data for all of the trees in your study area by selecting "Yes" or "No".\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 There are several different types of inventories that you can do for an i-Tree Eco project.\par If you plan to collect data for all of the trees in your study area, you will be doing a complete inventory. If this is the case, be sure to select "Yes" here.\par Another method of data collection is to establish plots within your study area. You would then collect data for all of the trees within your plots. This type of data collection means that you are collecting data for a sample of the trees in your study area and is called a plot-based inventory.\par } �

data.name: wpShowUnitsFromExistingProject
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par The units that you used in your original analysis are filled in by default. Make note of the units that you previously collected data in and select the "Next" button.\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 Units are an important project setting. This informs i-Tree Eco how your data will be collected so it can be properly entered and stored.\par One of the details to remember about a reinventory project is that many of the project settings have already been established, including the units used during data collection. The units that you selected in your original project must be used again when you collect your data for the reinventory project.\par \par } �

data.name: wpCollectAdditionalDataVariables
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par Indicate whether or not you would like to collect data for additional, custom fields by selecting "Yes" or "No".\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 i-Tree Eco gives you the option to collect additional, custom data for your project. This allows you to define additional fields that you are interested in and customize your project further.\par For example, you may decide that you would like to identify if the trees that you collect data for are invasive species or not. Adding custom data variables would allow you to include this in your analysis.\par } �

data.name: wpOptionalDataVariables
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par Choose the optional data variables that you will collect in the field by selecting the checkbox next to each variable.\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 There are many optional data variables that you can collect that make your i-Tree Eco analysis more robust. Some of the variables are tree specific data, while others relate to the site where you are collecting your data.\par Some data variables can be estimated by i-Tree Eco, but the more data you collect in the field the better your results will be. Keep in mind that choosing not to collect certain variables, such as IPED, means that some analyses will not be included in your final results. Additionally, some optional variables are more time intensive to collect than others.\par } �

data.name: wpSpecifyNewDatabase
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\par \b0 Create a new database to save your project in by browsing to the folder where you would like to save your database and giving the database a name. The new database name will appear in the box.\b\par Why It's Important:\par \b0 You have decided to save your new project data in a new database. The input that you provide here will inform i-Tree Eco to create a new database where all of your new project data will be saved.\par } �

data.name: wpSaveToCurrentDatabase
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\par \b0 Indicate whether or not you would like to save your new project data in the same database as your open project by selecting "Yes" or "No".\b\par Why It's Important:\par \b0 You have decided to save your new project in an existing database. You currently have a project open. You can choose to save your new project in the same database as your open project.\par If you would like to save your project in a different database, be sure to select "No." Also, make sure that you save your open project to ensure that no work is lost.\par } �

data.name: wpSelectExistingLocationForReinventory
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par Use the drop-down lists to identify the location, series name, and series year of the project that you are remeasuring.\b\par Why It's Important:\par \b0 You have decided that you will be completing a reinventory project. This means that you will be remeasuring data that you have collected in the past. \par The inputs that you provide here inform i-Tree Eco which project you will be doing a remeasurement of so the data can be loaded. Your existing project data can also be made available to you so you can reference it when you collect your new remeasurement data.\par } �

data.name: wpSelectCurrentProjectForReinventory
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\par \b0 Indicate whether or not you are doing a remeasurement of the project that you have open by selecting "Yes" or "No".\b\par Why It's Important:\par \b0 You have decided that you will be completing a reinventory project. This means that you will be remeasuring data that you have collected in the past. For this reason, you must inform i-Tree Eco where your previous project is saved.\par You currently have a project open. If the project that is open does not contain the data that you are remeasuring, be sure to select "No."\par } �

data.name: wpSelectUnits
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par Indicate whether you will be collecting your data in English units or metric units by clicking the radio button.\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 Units are an important project setting. This informs i-Tree Eco how your data will be collected so it can be properly entered and stored.\par } �

data.name: wpSetLinearCollection
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par Indicate whether or not you will be collecting data along a linear path by selecting "Yes" or "No".\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 You have indicated that you will be doing a plot-based inventory. A plot-based inventory is a method of data collection where you establish plots within your study area. You would then collect data for all of the trees within your plots. This type of data collection means that you are collecting data for a sample of the trees in your study area.\par When you establish plots for your project, you have the option to do a linear sample. A linear sample allows you to collect data along a linear path, such as a street, street segment, or utility right-of-way. For example, you might decide that you want to analyze only the trees that line the streets in your neighborhood. In this case, a linear sample is appropriate.\par } �

data.name: wpRequiredDataVariables
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 Reminder:\par \b0 There are two required data variables that you must collect in the field: species type and diameter at breast height (DBH).\par In order to complete an i-Tree Eco project, you need to have this informqation for each of the trees that you collect data for.\f1\fs22\par } �

data.name: wpDefiningAdditionalVariables
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par To define your additional variables, provide a field name in the space provided. Click on the "Define Variable" button next to each of the new variables you add. You will be prompted to identify the different codes that you will be using when you collect your data.\par \b Why It's Important:\b0\par You have indicated that you would like to add additional data collection variables. This allows you to create a more customized i-Tree Eco analysis.\par You may enter up to three additional variables that you will collect data for.\par Note that the data fields can not be open-ended but must be divisible into 10 or fewer categories. For example, a field called "General remarks" cannot be created, but a field called "Invasive" with categories "Yes" and "No" could be.\par } �

data.name: wpSelectYearReinventory
wpSpecifyNewDatabaseToSaveReinventory
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par Create a new database to save your project in by browsing to the folder where you would like to save your database and giving the database a name. The new database name will appear in the box.\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 You have decided to save your reinventory project in a new database. The input that you provide here will inform i-Tree Eco to create a new database where all of your reinventory data will be saved.\par \par } �

data.name: wpSelectExistingDatabase
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\par \b0 Indicate whether or not you would like to save your new project data in the same database as a previous project by selecting "Yes" or "No".\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 Data for your new project is saved within a database. i-Tree Eco allows you to save your data in either a new database or an existing database (that is, a database where a previous project has been saved).\par For example, you may live in a city that has 3 prominent parks. You would like to collect data to analyze each of these parks in a separate project.\par One of the reasons that you might want to store the data for these 3 parks together is that they are all located within the same city. However, you will still be able to analyze them separately.\par } �

data.name: wpSelectWeatherStationReinventory
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par The weather station you used in your original analysis is filled in by default when available.\par To select a different weather station, click on the "Show Map" button. In the window that appears, select the weather station that you would like to use in your analysis.\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 i-Tree Eco uses weather data to help estimate the ecosystem services, such as pollution removal, provided by the urban forest in your study area.\par One of the details to remember about a reinventory project is that many of the project settings have already been established, such as the location, series name, and type of data collection. When your series was originally created, you selected a weather station to use when the existing data was analyzed. You may choose to use this weather station again, but it is not required.\par \par } �

data.name: wpSelectYear
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par Enter a series year for your project in the box provided. Then, use the drop-down lists to select the year that you would like to use weather and pollution data for.\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 The year is an important setting in i-Tree Eco because it gives your project a unique identity and informs which datasets to use.\par The series year is used in conjunction with the project name and series name to help distinguish this project from other i-Tree Eco projects you may have. It is recommended that you enter the year of your data collection for this variable.\par i-Tree Eco uses weather and pollution data to help estimate the ecosystem services, such as pollution removal, provided by the urban forest in your study area. Weather and pollution data are available for 2005 to 2010.\par } �

data.name: wpSelectExistingDatabaseForReinventory
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}{\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Calibri;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par Choose the existing database where your project for remeasurement is saved by browsing to the folder where it is saved and selecting it. After selected, the existing database name will appear in the box.\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 You have decided that you will be completing a reinventory project. This means that you will be remeasuring data that you have collected in the past. For this reason, you must inform i-Tree Eco where your previous project is saved.\par \f1\fs22\par } �

data.name: wpIntro
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\f0\fs18\lang9 The New Project Wizard acts as a project setup assistant. You will be asked a series of questions that will make it easier for you to design your new i-Tree Eco project.\par If you are already familiar with i-Tree Eco and would like to start a new project without using the wizard, please be sure to select "No." Check the box at the bottom of the window and the wizard will not appear in the future.\par To access the wizard from the i-Tree Eco window go to the New Project Wizard tool located in the Help tab of the ribbon.\par Additional help for users migrating from i-Tree Streets to i-Tree Eco is available at the following link:\par Video tutorials available here:\par } �

data.name: wpSeriesName
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par Enter a series name for your project in the box provided.\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 The series name is an important setting in i-Tree Eco because it gives your project a unique identity.\par For the majority of new projects, a new series is created. However, in the future you can choose to add data to an existing series. This type of project is a reinventory and is done only if you plan to remeasure data that you collected previously. In this instance, your series name is used to reference your past data collection and identify where your new data will be added. \par } �

data.name: wpSelectNewWeatherStation
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par Select your weather station by clicking on the "Show Map" button. In the window that appears, select the weather station that you would like to use in your analysis.\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 i-Tree Eco uses weather data to help estimate the ecosystem services, such as pollution removal, provided by the urban forest in your study area.\par Please note that depending on the weather year you choose, certain weather stations may not be available. If there is a weather station that you know you would like to choose and it does not appear on the map, you may need to change the weather year.\par \par } �

data.name: wpSpecifyNewLocation
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par Select the location where the majority of your study area is located using the drop-down lists.\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 Location is an important project setting in i-Tree Eco for many reasons. It is used to provide localized benefit estimates. That is, many of the ecosystem service analyses rely on national, state, or county-level data.\par Please note that i-Tree Eco allows you to enter a county as your location. You are not required to choose a place. However, if you are doing a project that is not at the county scale, a more refined location may provide better estimates.\par } �

data.name: wpConfirmingSettings
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par The project configuration and data collection settings that you have chosen are displayed on the right. Scroll through the list of settings and review them. Changes can be made by clicking on the "Edit" button next to each setting.\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 Now is the time to review all of the decisions that you have made throughout the New Project Wizard. Carefully look at the settings and confirm that your i-Tree Eco project meets your needs.\par Once you have created your project, you will not have another opportunity to do this.\par } �

data.name: wpRemeasure
data.value:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs18\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par Indicate whether or not you are taking remeasurements of data that has been collected in the past by selecting "Yes" or "No".\par \b Why It's Important:\b0\par
\pard\lang1033 There are different types of new projects that you can complete in i-Tree Eco, including a reinventory. A reinventory project is a project where you plan to remeasure trees that you previously collected data for.\par \par For example, you may have collected data for all of the trees within a park in 2004. In 2014, you decided that you would like to go back to the same park and collect data for the trees again.\par \par One of the reasons that you might want to complete a reinventory project would be to analyze how the urban forest in your study area is changing over time.\lang9\par } �

data.name: wpSpecifyReinventorySeriesYear
data.value: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\nouicompat\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Tahoma;}} {\*\generator Riched20 6.3.9600}\viewkind4\uc1 \pard\sa200\sl276\slmult1\b\f0\fs16\lang9 What To Do:\b0\par Enter a series year for your project in the box provided.\par \b Why It's Important:\par \b0 A reinventory project means that you are adding data to an existing series by remeasuring data that you collected in the past. One of the ways that you differentiate your new data from the old data in the series is by defining your series year.\par The series year for your new data must be different from the series year that you used in the past.\par For example, if you choose to collect data for all of the trees in a park in 2000 then remeasure that park in 2014 these data will be saved within the same series. By giving each set of data a different series year, such as 2000 and 2014, you will be able to look at the datasets separately and compare them to each other.\par \par } �
